title: Giant (monster)

* is [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivore "Carnivore").
* is a giant.
* is [nasty](/wiki/M2_NASTY "M2 NASTY").
* is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong").
* can throw boulders.
* likes gems.
* can pick up weapons and food.
* has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").
* can be seen through [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). |                                                      |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |                                                      |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                | [monst.c#line1388](/wiki/Monst.c#line1388 "Monst.c") |

A **giant**, H, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a type of [giant](/wiki/Giant_\(monster_attribute\) "Giant (monster attribute)") that serves as the base monster for the [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") left by a [giant zombie](/wiki/Giant_zombie "Giant zombie") or [giant mummy](/wiki/Giant_mummy "Giant mummy"). Its stats are identical to those of the [stone giant](/wiki/Stone_giant "Stone giant").

A giant has a single weapon attack.

[Eating](/wiki/Eating "Eating") a giant corpse or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 1⁄2 chance (50%) of increasing a character's [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The attacks of giants and other sufficiently large monsters can inflict knockback, sending targets flying one or more squares.

Giants and other large humanoids can wear mummy wrappings.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [4.3 SporkHack](#SporkHack)
  - [4.4 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [4.5 NetHack Fourk](#NetHack_Fourk)
  - [4.6 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [4.7 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [4.8 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Standard giants are [not randomly generated](/wiki/Normal_mechanism "Normal mechanism").

A giant zombie or giant mummy will leave an aged human [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") behind upon death.[\[1\]](#cite_note-undead_to_corpse-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-make_corpse-2) Giants can also be generated by zapping a [wand of undead turning](/wiki/Wand_of_undead_turning "Wand of undead turning") at a giant corpse that is *not* left by a zombie or mummy, [wishing](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for a [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of a giant and [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") it, or else selecting giants while reading a [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") [scroll of genocide](/wiki/Scroll_of_genocide "Scroll of genocide").

Giants that are somehow generated normally have a 1⁄2 chance (50%) of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") either a boulder or a [club](/wiki/Club "Club") with equal probability, and an independent chance of being generated with a small assortment of gems.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) They are eligible for [offensive items](/wiki/Offensive_item "Offensive item"), [defensive items](/wiki/Defensive_item "Defensive item"), and [miscellaneous items](/wiki/Miscellaneous_item "Miscellaneous item").

## Strategy

Giant corpses left behind by zombies and mummies can be a risky source of additional strength for characters, due to the chance of contracting [food poisoning](/wiki/Food_poisoning "Food poisoning"). A [tinning kit](/wiki/Tinning_kit "Tinning kit") can render them both safe to consume and much less [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition")-heavy.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Knockback can make giants and other large monsters exceedingly dangerous if the player character is positioned between them and a hazard, such as [pools](/wiki/Pool "Pool") of water or [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava"). This also includes giant zombies and mummies, which can make it more difficult to obtain their corpses in some situations.

## History

The giant first appears in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d"). From this version to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"), the monster uses the 9 glyph.

[NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0") moves the giant to the [giant humanoid](/wiki/Giant_humanoid "Giant humanoid") monster class and introduces most of the distinct giant types minus the [storm giant](/wiki/Storm_giant "Storm giant") - the standard giant remains in the game's data as a placeholder for the corpse left by the giant zombie and giant mummy, which are introduced in the same version.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), 20 giants are generated in the [Giant Caverns](/wiki/Giant_Caverns "Giant Caverns") at level generation.

### GruntHack

- *Main article: [Giant (starting race)](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)")*

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), giants are a playable race, and they also generate as [racial monsters](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") - both leave behind giant corpses upon death. The giant's [level](/wiki/Monster_level "Monster level") is lowered to 3, and its [monster difficulty](/wiki/Monster_difficulty "Monster difficulty") is also lowered to 4.

### SporkHack

- *Main article: [Giant (starting race)](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)")*

[SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack") includes the giant as a playable race.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), giants are neutral-aligned and vulnerable to [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"). They have an additional 1⁄4 chance (25%) of being generated with a club, due to an oversight in the code.

Giants may appear among the court of a [titan](/wiki/Titan "Titan")-ruled [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room#dNetHack "Throne room").

### NetHack Fourk

- *Main article: [Giant (starting race)](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)")*

[NetHack Fourk](/wiki/NetHack_Fourk "NetHack Fourk") includes the giant as a playable race, and standard giants now generate randomly: they are used as a replacement for the stone giant due to its identical stats, and are generated in the same locations that stone giants are in *NetHack*.

### EvilHack

- *Main article: [Giant (starting race)](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)")*

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), giants are also a playable race and can generate as racial monsters, similar to GruntHack. The giant's stats are changed to reflect its status as a placeholder: its monster level is lowered to 0, its difficulty is lowered 2, its [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") is set to 6, and its weapon attack can inflict knockback like other giants.

### SlashTHEM

- *Main article: [Giant (starting race)](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)")*

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, the giant is also a playable race: the monster is given a second weapon attack with the same dice to reflect the role's [twoweapon](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon") ability, and its monster difficulty is increased to 11.

### Hack'EM

- *Main article: [Giant (starting race)](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)")*

[Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") adds giants as a playable race, and they generate as the same racial monsters as in EvilHack, with the same stat changes applied. The giant monster no longer appears in the Giant Caverns, and each instance is replaced with random giant humanoids.

## Encyclopedia entry

Giants have always walked the earth, though they are rare in these times. They range in size from little over nine feet to a towering twenty feet or more. The larger ones use huge boulders as weapons, hurling them over large distances. All types of giants share a love for men - roasted, boiled, or fried. Their table manners are legendary.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-undead_to_corpse_1-0) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 147](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L147): *Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-make_corpse_2-0) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 372](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L372): *Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 183](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L183)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 706](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L706)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Giant (monster)

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
H giant
Difficulty 8
Attacks Weapon 2d10
H giant
Difficulty 8
Attacks

Weapon 2d10

Base level 6
Base experience 127
Speed 6
Base AC 0
Base MR 0
Alignment 2 (lawful)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 2250
Nutritional value 750
Size Huge
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed Increase strength (50%)

A giant:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is a giant.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • can throw boulders.
  • likes gems.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line1388

A giant, H, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is a type of giant that serves as the base monster for the corpse left by a giant zombie or giant mummy. Its stats are identical to those of the stone giant.

A giant has a single weapon attack.

Eating a giant corpse or tin has a 1⁄2 chance (50%) of increasing a character's strength.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

The attacks of giants and other sufficiently large monsters can inflict knockback, sending targets flying one or more squares.

Giants and other large humanoids can wear mummy wrappings.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SLASH'EM
    • 4.2 GruntHack
    • 4.3 SporkHack
    • 4.4 dNetHack
    • 4.5 NetHack Fourk
    • 4.6 EvilHack
    • 4.7 SlashTHEM
    • 4.8 Hack'EM
  • 5 Encyclopedia entry
  • 6 References

Generation

Standard giants are not randomly generated.

A giant zombie or giant mummy will leave an aged human corpse behind upon death.[1][2] Giants can also be generated by zapping a wand of undead turning at a giant corpse that is not left by a zombie or mummy, wishing for a figurine of a giant and applying it, or else selecting giants while reading a cursed scroll of genocide.

Giants that are somehow generated normally have a 1⁄2 chance (50%) of being generated with either a boulder or a club with equal probability, and an independent chance of being generated with a small assortment of gems.[3][4] They are eligible for offensive items, defensive items, and miscellaneous items.

Strategy

Giant corpses left behind by zombies and mummies can be a risky source of additional strength for characters, due to the chance of contracting food poisoning. A tinning kit can render them both safe to consume and much less nutrition-heavy.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Knockback can make giants and other large monsters exceedingly dangerous if the player character is positioned between them and a hazard, such as pools of water or lava. This also includes giant zombies and mummies, which can make it more difficult to obtain their corpses in some situations.

History

The giant first appears in NetHack 1.3d. From this version to NetHack 2.3e, the monster uses the 9 glyph.

NetHack 3.0.0 moves the giant to the giant humanoid monster class and introduces most of the distinct giant types minus the storm giant - the standard giant remains in the game's data as a placeholder for the corpse left by the giant zombie and giant mummy, which are introduced in the same version.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, 20 giants are generated in the Giant Caverns at level generation.

GruntHack

Main article: Giant (starting race)

In GruntHack, giants are a playable race, and they also generate as racial monsters - both leave behind giant corpses upon death. The giant's level is lowered to 3, and its monster difficulty is also lowered to 4.

SporkHack

Main article: Giant (starting race)

SporkHack includes the giant as a playable race.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, giants are neutral-aligned and vulnerable to iron. They have an additional 1⁄4 chance (25%) of being generated with a club, due to an oversight in the code.

Giants may appear among the court of a titan-ruled throne room.

NetHack Fourk

Main article: Giant (starting race)

NetHack Fourk includes the giant as a playable race, and standard giants now generate randomly: they are used as a replacement for the stone giant due to its identical stats, and are generated in the same locations that stone giants are in NetHack.

EvilHack

Main article: Giant (starting race)

In EvilHack, giants are also a playable race and can generate as racial monsters, similar to GruntHack. The giant's stats are changed to reflect its status as a placeholder: its monster level is lowered to 0, its difficulty is lowered 2, its AC is set to 6, and its weapon attack can inflict knockback like other giants.

SlashTHEM

Main article: Giant (starting race)

In SlashTHEM, in addition to SLASH'EM details, the giant is also a playable race: the monster is given a second weapon attack with the same dice to reflect the role's twoweapon ability, and its monster difficulty is increased to 11.

Hack'EM

Main article: Giant (starting race)

Hack'EM adds giants as a playable race, and they generate as the same racial monsters as in EvilHack, with the same stat changes applied. The giant monster no longer appears in the Giant Caverns, and each instance is replaced with random giant humanoids.

Encyclopedia entry

Giants have always walked the earth, though they are rare in these times. They range in size from little over nine feet to a towering twenty feet or more. The larger ones use huge boulders as weapons, hurling them over large distances. All types of giants share a love for men - roasted, boiled, or fried. Their table manners are legendary.

References

  1. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 147: Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts
  2. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 372: Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops
  3. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 183
  4. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 706

A '''giant''', {{monsym|giant}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a type of [[Giant (monster attribute)|giant]] that serves as the base monster for the [[corpse]] left by a [[giant zombie]] or [[giant mummy]]. Its stats are identical to those of the [[stone giant]].

A giant has a single weapon attack.

[[Eating]] a giant corpse or [[tin]] has a {{frac|2}} chance (50%) of increasing a character's [[strength]].

{{upcoming|3.7.0|The attacks of giants and other sufficiently large monsters can inflict knockback, sending targets flying one or more squares.

Giants and other large humanoids can wear mummy wrappings.}}

==Generation==
Standard giants are [[Normal mechanism|not randomly generated]].

A giant zombie or giant mummy will leave an aged human [[corpse]] behind upon death.{{refsrc|src/mon.c|147|nethack=3.6.7|name="undead_to_corpse"|comment=Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts}}{{refsrc|src/mon.c|372|nethack=3.6.7|name="make_corpse"|comment=Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops}} Giants can also be generated by zapping a [[wand of undead turning]] at a giant corpse that is ''not'' left by a zombie or mummy, [[wish]]ing for a [[figurine]] of a giant and [[apply]]ing it, or else selecting giants while reading a [[cursed]] [[scroll of genocide]].

Giants that are somehow generated normally have a {{frac|2}} chance (50%) of [[Monster starting inventory|being generated with]] either a boulder or a [[club]] with equal probability, and an independent chance of being generated with a small assortment of gems.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|183|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|706|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} They are eligible for [[offensive item]]s, [[defensive item]]s, and [[miscellaneous item]]s.

==Strategy==
Giant corpses left behind by zombies and mummies can be a risky source of additional strength for characters, due to the chance of contracting [[food poisoning]]. A [[tinning kit]] can render them both safe to consume and much less [[nutrition]]-heavy.

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Knockback can make giants and other large monsters exceedingly dangerous if the player character is positioned between them and a hazard, such as [[pool]]s of water or [[lava]]. This also includes giant zombies and mummies, which can make it more difficult to obtain their corpses in some situations.}}

==History==
The giant first appears in [[NetHack 1.3d]]. From this version to [[NetHack 2.3e]], the monster uses the {{white|9}} glyph.

[[NetHack 3.0.0]] moves the giant to the [[giant humanoid]] monster class and introduces most of the distinct giant types minus the [[storm giant]] - the standard giant remains in the game's data as a placeholder for the corpse left by the giant zombie and giant mummy, which are introduced in the same version.

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], 20 giants are generated in the [[Giant Caverns]] at level generation.

===GruntHack===
{{main|Giant (starting race)}}
In [[GruntHack]], giants are a playable race, and they also generate as [[racial monster]]s - both leave behind giant corpses upon death. The giant's [[Monster level|level]] is lowered to 3, and its [[monster difficulty]] is also lowered to 4.

===SporkHack===
{{main|Giant (starting race)}}
[[SporkHack]] includes the giant as a playable race.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], giants are neutral-aligned and vulnerable to [[iron]]. They have an additional {{frac|4}} chance (25%) of being generated with a club, due to an oversight in the code.

Giants may appear among the court of a [[titan]]-ruled [[Throne room#dNetHack|throne room]].

===NetHack Fourk===
{{main|Giant (starting race)}}
[[NetHack Fourk]] includes the giant as a playable race, and standard giants now generate randomly: they are used as a replacement for the stone giant due to its identical stats, and are generated in the same locations that stone giants are in ''NetHack''.

===EvilHack===
{{main|Giant (starting race)}}
In [[EvilHack]], giants are also a playable race and can generate as racial monsters, similar to GruntHack. The giant's stats are changed to reflect its status as a placeholder: its monster level is lowered to 0, its difficulty is lowered 2, its [[AC]] is set to 6, and its weapon attack can inflict knockback like other giants.

===SlashTHEM===
{{main|Giant (starting race)}}
In [[SlashTHEM]], in addition to SLASH'EM details, the giant is also a playable race: the monster is given a second weapon attack with the same dice to reflect the role's [[twoweapon]] ability, and its monster difficulty is increased to 11.

===Hack'EM===
{{main|Giant (starting race)}}
[[Hack'EM]] adds giants as a playable race, and they generate as the same racial monsters as in EvilHack, with the same stat changes applied. The giant monster no longer appears in the Giant Caverns, and each instance is replaced with random giant humanoids.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|Giants have always walked the earth, though they are rare in these times.  They range in size from little over nine feet to a towering twenty feet or more.  The larger ones use huge boulders as weapons, hurling them over large distances.  All types of giants share a love for men - roasted, boiled, or fried.  Their table manners are legendary.
}}
